title: 108_s1890
content: The Act titled "Stock Option Accounting Reform Act" mandates the expensing of stock options held by highly compensated officers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require the expensing of stock options for named executive officers and the four most highly compensated executive officers of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires registered issuers to expense the fair value of stock options granted to named executive officers after December 31, 2004. The fair value is determined by the value agreed upon by willing buyers and sellers, considering all characteristics and restrictions of the option. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires registered issuers to expense the fair value of stock options granted to named executive officers. The fair value is determined using option pricing models like Black-Scholes or binomial models, with assumed volatility of zero for underlying stock. Exemptions apply to small business issuers with annual revenues less than $25,000,000, organized under US or Canadian laws, and not investment companies. The option to purchase the stock of an issuer granted after such date is subject to specific regulations. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON EXPENSING AND ECONOMIC IMPACT STUDY. Prohibition on expensing standards related to stock options under the Securities Act of 1933, requiring compliance with specific requirements and completion of an economic impact study. The exercise, forfeiture, or expiration of stock options subject to section 13(m) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 will result in the reported expenses being reduced in the fiscal year of expiration or forfeiture. Any excess reduction will offset total option expenses for that fiscal year. The Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Labor will conduct a joint study on the economic impact of mandatory expensing of employee stock options, focusing on broad-based plans, recruitment, innovation, economic growth, and corporate ownership.
